docTitle.titlePart: Statement on Birth Control and the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps

sourceDesc.bibl: Birth control urged for WAAC by Sanger Philidelphia Daily News June 10, 1942

headNote.p: Sanger's statement on the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps was picked up by multiple newspapers, including the New York Times Herald.

docBody.head: Birth control urged for WAAC by Sanger

q.p: The government should give members of the women’s army auxiliary corps “preventive measures against pregnancy, just as it gives them protection against smallpox,” Margaret Sanger, the nation’s prime advocate of birth control, urged today.

div.p: She coupled the suggestions with a dire warning that otherwise the no-babies rule of the WAAC will become “a Frankenstein monster which will turn and wreck the corps.”

Miss Sanger, founder and honorary president of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America was referring to the WAAC regulation that any member of the corps who becomes pregnant will be immediately discharged. “Abortions and illegitimacy are bound to result if the government doesn’t recognize human nature,” she said.
Asserting that “women should not be exposed to coming down with a baby any more than to coming down with yellow fever,” Miss Sanger continued.

“Women in the army should receive the same instruction and the same protection as men soldiers. The women’s army will grow to great usefulness or disintegrate on the old-fashioned problem of woman as the child bearer and sex convenience – which is her status in the Nazi countries.
“It is up to women to make a clear, concise and courageous statement of their position at this time, before it is too late, and demand protection and equal treatment with men in this matter.

div.head: More of Her Argument
div.p: “If she does not rise to this responsibility, with a courageous and scientific attitude about her sex, she will set back the cause of women’s rights hundreds of years. Women cannot afford to let the women’s army be wrecked on prudery or outworn notions.”
